project.name: In-App Products Module for iOS
project.description: The Logical Labs In-App Products module provides Titanium developers access to features related to in-app product purchases.

Readme.name: Readme
Readme.description: ## Introduction This module allows the Titanium developer to provide in-app products. ## Usage **Note**: This module provides functionality that **will not work** in the simulator. Please run your tests on an actual device. This module provides access to the products defined in iTunes Connect. You will need to add your app to iTunes Connect and define the in-app products there. The following code segments are not complete; they only demonstrate the essentials of using the module. See example/app.js for a complete example. You load the module as usual: var InAppProducts = require('com.logicallabs.inappproducts'); Basic steps to get a list of available products: InAppProducts.addEventListener('receivedProducts', function(e) { e.products.forEach(... }); if (InAppProducts.getProducts({ SKUs: productIDs })) { Ti.API.info('getProducts request started successfully.'); } else { alert('Error: could not start getProducts request!'); } Basic steps to purchase a product: InAppProducts.addEventListener('purchaseUpdate', function(e) { switch (e.purchase.state) { ... }); productObj.purchase(); ## Completing a Purchase The purchase process of in-app products on iOS separates the steps of completing the payment and completing the purchase itself. When the payment for the product is received, the related {{#crossLink "Purchase"}}{{/crossLink}} object goes into {{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/PURCHASE\_STATE\_PURCHASED:attribute"}} {{/crossLink}} state. This signals to the app that the purchased functionality should be made available to the user in the app's environment. Once the app completed the processing of a purchase, it must call the {{#crossLink "Purchase/complete:method"}}{{/crossLink}} method. If the app fails to do this, perhaps because it is terminated before it can completely process the purchase, it will receive a {{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/purchaseUpdate:event"}}{{/crossLink}} event for the uncompleted purchase the next time it starts up. The module will cache these events until the {{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/purchaseUpdate:event"}}{{/crossLink}} event handler becomes available and then deliver all the outstanding events at once. For this reason it is important to prepare this event handler for handling such seemingly unsolicited events. ## Issues and Limitations Web receipt verification with the iTunes Store is not part of the module at this time -- the best practice encouraged by Apple is to perform this verification on an independent server, not on the device. ## Change Log ### Version 1.0.0 * First release ## Author titanium@logicallabs.com ## License Logical Labs Commercial License ## Copyright Copyright (c) 2013 by Logical Labs, LLC

Download.name: Download
Download.description:
A Download object represents downloadable content associated with a product.
When you create a product in iTunes Connect, you can associate one or more
pieces of downloadable content with it. Then, at runtime, when a product is
purchased by a user, your app uses Download objects to download the content
from the App Store.

classitems.description:
Notifies the app about a change in the state of the module. See the
{{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/state:property"}}
{{/crossLink}} property for more information.

On iOS, this event is only provided for compatibility with Android.
It is only fired once, when the module is loaded, and
the state is always
{{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/STATE\_READY:attribute"}}
{{/crossLink}}.
classitems.name: stateChange

{{/crossLink}} property when the system cannot determine how much time is
needed to finish downloading the content.

One of the possible values of the
{{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/state:property"}}
{{/crossLink}} property.

This value means that the app is running in the simulator.
This module provides functionality that **will not work** in the
simulator. Please run your tests on an actual device.
classitems.name: STATE_NOT_SUPPORTED

classitems.description:
One of the possible values returned by the
{{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/getSupportStatus:method"}}
{{/crossLink}} method.

This value means that none of the product types are supported.
classitems.name: SUPPORT_STATUS_NONE

classitems.description:
One of the possible values returned by the
{{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/getSupportStatus:method"}}
{{/crossLink}} method.

This value means that all the product types are supported.
classitems.name: SUPPORT_STATUS_ALL

classitems.description:
One of the possible values returned by the
{{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/getSupportStatus:method"}}
{{/crossLink}} method.

This value means that an error occurred while querying the support
status.
classitems.name: SUPPORT_STATUS_ERROR

state

classitems.description:
Determines whether billing is supported. Note that the return
value is a number, not a simple boolean in order to accommodate the more
elaborate equivalent function on Android. Use the
{{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/SUPPORT\_STATUS\_NONE:attribute"}}
{{/crossLink}} and
{{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/SUPPORT\_STATUS\_ALL:attribute"}}
{{/crossLink}} constants to interpret the returned value.
classitems.name: getSupportStatus

return.description:
See the SUPPORT\_STATUS\_* constants for possible
values.

classitems.description:
Requests product information for the provided SKUs from iTunes Store.

The final result of this operation is reported via the
{{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/receivedProducts:event"}}
{{/crossLink}} event.
classitems.name: getProducts

classitems.name: getPurchases

return.description: true if the recovery was initiated successfully.

classitems.description: Defines whether the module will automatically mark the purchases completed. **By default** this property is set to false in order to avoid a situation where a purchase gets "lost" due to a crash in the application. This can happen if the module marks the purchase completed before the application has a chance to processed the purchase and unlocked the functionality purchased by the user. If this property is set to true, the module will mark every purchase in the {{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/PURCHASE\_STATE\_PURCHASED:attribute"}} {{/crossLink}}, {{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/PURCHASE\_STATE\_FAILED:attribute"}} {{/crossLink}}, and {{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/PURCHASE\_STATE\_RESTORED:attribute"}} {{/crossLink}} state. If this property is set to false, which is the default, then it is the **responsibility of the app** to do the same by calling the {{#crossLink "Purchase/complete:method"}} {{/crossLink}} method.
classitems.name: autoCompletePurchases

classitems.description: The semantics of this event are significantly different on iOS and Android. On iOS, this event is tied to the paymentQueue:updatedTransactions: native callback function. On iOS, just like on Android, this event reports the result of a call to the {{#crossLink "Product/purchase:method"}} {{/crossLink}}. In addition, this event is sent for each purchase that is restored as a result of a call to {{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/getPurchases:method"}} {{/crossLink}}. Furthermore, you will receive this event when your app starts up if there are any pending purchases. A pending purchase is one that has not been completed either by explicitly calling the {{#crossLink "Purchase/complete:method"}} {{/crossLink}} method or implicitly (by the module) in case the {{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/autoCompletePurchase:property"}} {{/crossLink}} property is set to true. The app will end up with a pending purchase if it crashes before it can record the fact that a purchase took place. Therefore it is a good idea to attach the purchaseUpdate event handler to the module as soon as possible during the startup of the app and process any and all pending purchases. This way the app's user will have access to the purchased functionality immediately.

An array
{{#crossLink "Purchase"}}
{{/crossLink}} objects. Note that this attribute is present and may contain

The error message; only present if

classitems.description:
Starts downloading the specificed content. In order for a download object to
be queued for downloading, it must be associated with a purchase that has not
been finished yet.
classitems.name: startDownloads

classitems.description: Pauses a set of downloads.
classitems.name: pauseDownloads

classitems.description: Resumes a set of downloads.
classitems.name: resumeDownloads

classitems.description: Cancels downloading the specificed content.
classitems.name: cancelDownloads
downloadUpdate

classitems.description: A string that uniquely identifies the downloadable content.
classitems.name: contentID

classitems.description: The length of the downloadable content, in bytes.
classitems.name: contentLength

classitems.description:
The local location of the downloaded file.

The value of this property is valid only when the 
{{#crossLink "Download/state:property"}}
{{/crossLink}} property
is set to
{{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/DOWNLOAD\_STATE\_FINISHED:attribute"}}
{{/crossLink}}.

The URL becomes invalid after the purchase associated with the download
is completed.
classitems.name: contentURL

classitems.description:
A string that identifies which version of the content is available for
download.
The version string must be formatted as a series of integers separated by 
periods.
classitems.name: contentVersion
state

classitems.description: The code of the error that prevented the content from being downloaded.
classitems.name: errorCode

classitems.description: The error message associated with a failed download.
classitems.name: errorMessage

classitems.description:
A value that indicates how much of the file has been downloaded.

The value of this property is a floating point number between 0.0 and 1.0,
inclusive, where 0.0 means no data has been download and 1.0 means all the
data has been downloaded. Typically, your app uses the value of this property
to update a user interface element, such as a progress bar, that displays how
much of the file has been downloaded.

Do not use the value of this property to determine whether the download has
completed. Instead, use the
{{#crossLink "Download/state:property"}}
{{/crossLink}} property.
classitems.name: progress

classitems.description:
An estimated time, in seconds, to finish downloading the content.

The system attempts to estimate how long it will take to finish downloading
the file. If it cannot create a good estimate, the value of this property is
set to
{{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/DOWNLOAD\_TIME\_UNKNOWN:attribute"}}
{{/crossLink}},
classitems.name: timeRemaining

classitems.description: Product description.
classitems.name: description

classitems.description: Product title.
classitems.name: title

classitems.description: Product price as number.
classitems.name: priceAsNumber

classitems.description: Product price as string, formatted for correct locale.
classitems.name: priceAsString

classitems.description: The locale used to format the price of the product.
classitems.name: priceLocale

classitems.description: The product identifier.
classitems.name: SKU

classitems.description: Begins purchase process for provided product

params.name: params
params.description: An object with the following properties:

props.name: applicationPayload
props.description:
An opaque identifier for the user’s
account on your system. This is used to help the store detect irregular
activity. For example, in a game, it would be unusual for dozens of different
iTunes Store accounts making purchases on behalf of the same in-game
character. The recommended implementation is to use a one-way hash of the
user’s account name to calculate the value for this property. Optional,
defaults null.

props.name: quantity
props.description:
Number of products to purchase. Optional,
defaults to 1.

classitems.description: Purchase state.
classitems.name: state
errorCode
errorMessage
receipt

classitems.description: Time of purchase.
classitems.name: time

classitems.description: A unique order identifier for the transaction.
classitems.name: orderNumber

classitems.description: Number of products purchased.
classitems.name: quantity

classitems.description:
An opaque identifier for the user’s
account on your system. Only available on iOS7.0 and above.
classitems.name: applicationPayload

classitems.description: The item's product identifier.
classitems.name: SKU

classitems.description:
The original purchase associated with this (restored) purchase.
Only valid if the state is
{{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/PURCHASE\_STATE\_RESTORED:attribute"}}
{{/crossLink}}.

downloads

classitems.description: Marks the purchase as completed. Your application should call this method from the {{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/purchaseUpdate:event"}} {{/crossLink}} event handler after it has successfully processed the purchase and unlocked the functionality purchased by the user. Note that on iOS, you will receive a {{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/purchaseUpdate:event"}} {{/crossLink}} event not only in response to the Alternatively, you can set the {{#crossLink "InAppProductsModule/autoCompletePurchase:property"}} {{/crossLink}} property to true; that will cause the module to automatically complete the purchase right before
classitems.name: complete
